page.title: 11Historic Buildings 2
page.content: The early prosperity of Trefriw resulted from its popularity as a hydropathic centre, until the second world war,when the Conwy silted up,so that the river steamers were no longer able to disembark passengers here.The wells had been known since Roman times when the "caves" may have been excavated in their searches for lead.There are two springs, one very rich in iron, the other in sulphur.The waters have never been known to fail even in severe drought- a rare occurrence in this region of heavy rainfall! After falling into disuse the Pump house became derelict, but was restored some years ago, and is now a private dwelling. Steps near this building are carved with symbols believed to be Early Christian in origin.
